description: When you are first start programming, solving problems can be difficult. Since the entire impetus for learning programming is to solve a multitude of problems with a computer, the difficulties can lead to frustration. However, in this course, we are going to approach a problem with a method that can help alleviate those issues. Join us as we develop our problem-solving toolkit!

Since the entire impetus for learning programming is to solve a multitude of problems with a computer, the difficulties can lead to frustration. However, in this course, we are going to approach a problem with a method that can help alleviate those issues. Join us as we develop our problem-solving toolkit!
name: Algorithmic Problem Solving
subtitle: Problem Solving Step by Step

episodes.description: When you are first start programming, solving problems can be difficult. Since the entire impetus for learning programming is to solve a multitude of problems with a computer, the difficulties can lead to frustration. However, in this course, we are going to approach a problem with a method that can help alleviate those issues. Join us as we develop our problem-solving toolkit!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.939
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.939 --> 00:00:06.731
>> Hello and thank you for
watching DevProTV,

3
00:00:06.731 --> 00:00:09.697
we're talking to Justin Dennison
about algorithmic problem solving.

4
00:00:09.697 --> 00:00:12.540
So Justin, tell us about the course.

5
00:00:12.540 --> 00:00:17.160
>> The course is meant to allow
to us think about how to plan.

6
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:18.522
How to kind of grock,

7
00:00:18.522 --> 00:00:23.610
which is a terminology that means just
fully understand a respective problem.

8
00:00:23.610 --> 00:00:27.246
And in this course, what we're gonna do
is we're gonna take an approach of, well,

9
00:00:27.246 --> 00:00:28.730
how do I approach a problem?

10
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:31.163
How do I algorithmically
approach something?

11
00:00:31.163 --> 00:00:35.730
And that's up for debate.

12
00:00:35.730 --> 00:00:39.568
This is a little bit of a biased
opinion here, so in this course.

13
00:00:39.568 --> 00:00:44.392
But with them, we'll have a series of
projects where we have planning phase and

14
00:00:44.392 --> 00:00:45.400
a coding phase.

15
00:00:45.400 --> 00:00:48.142
So the planing will be let me draw,
what do I know?

16
00:00:48.142 --> 00:00:50.268
How do these things work?

17
00:00:50.268 --> 00:00:51.943
Let's see if I can break it and

18
00:00:51.943 --> 00:00:55.766
it's more about understanding
what's called the problem space.

19
00:00:55.766 --> 00:00:59.410
Instead of just going well,
let me write some code here.

20
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:04.298
So the entire goal is to solve actual
problems though, they are small in

21
00:01:04.298 --> 00:01:09.105
nature by applying a process that
should be applicable over a larger,

22
00:01:09.105 --> 00:01:11.151
more complex problem space.

23
00:01:11.151 --> 00:01:13.520
>> And Justin,
who is this show targeted towards?

24
00:01:13.520 --> 00:01:15.890
>> This is someone who's maybe just
getting started with programming,

25
00:01:15.890 --> 00:01:17.384
maybe wants to know
a little bit more about.

26
00:01:17.384 --> 00:01:19.344
Maybe they programmed before, but

27
00:01:19.344 --> 00:01:24.490
they're like I'm having trouble figuring
out what I'm supposed to do next.

28
00:01:24.490 --> 00:01:31.166
This show is to help those individuals
say, I need to do thing X.

29
00:01:31.166 --> 00:01:33.680
How do I accomplish thing X?

30
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:37.388
Well, I need to follow these
kind of steps in order to okay,

31
00:01:37.388 --> 00:01:39.919
that's how I put all of these together.

32
00:01:39.919 --> 00:01:43.570
So the goal is to help people
who are having trouble.

33
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:45.264
Maybe they know a little bit,
maybe they don't.

34
00:01:45.264 --> 00:01:50.254
How do I actually accomplish things that
I have original ideas for that maybe I

35
00:01:50.254 --> 00:01:55.830
don't know where to get started or how
to progress in some reproducible manner.

36
00:01:55.830 --> 00:01:57.897
>> Is there a certification available for
the course?

37
00:01:57.897 --> 00:01:59.900
>> This is not a certification course.

38
00:01:59.900 --> 00:02:03.325
This is kind of one of those heady
topics where we're gonna do a little

39
00:02:03.325 --> 00:02:04.221
bit of thinking.

40
00:02:04.221 --> 00:02:06.393
And by a little bit, I mean, a lot and

41
00:02:06.393 --> 00:02:09.350
then we're gonna make sure
we have some drawing.

42
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:13.148
I'm gonna try to show you my
thought process, which maybe you

43
00:02:13.148 --> 00:02:17.910
might have to tweak for yourself and
then we're going to do the application.

44
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:22.580
As a result, it would be very hard
to certify something like this.

45
00:02:22.580 --> 00:02:25.057
You're a certified
algorithm problem solver.

46
00:02:25.057 --> 00:02:29.780
So this is more about getting better
in order to move forward in your craft.

47
00:02:29.780 --> 00:02:32.503
>> And you've already kind of test on it,
but what topics are covered in this show?

48
00:02:32.503 --> 00:02:36.304
>> So that the topics are mostly
in an abstract sense planning and

49
00:02:36.304 --> 00:02:38.801
then actually implementing or coding.

50
00:02:38.801 --> 00:02:41.952
But along that, we're gonna be
building a Caesar sign for it.

51
00:02:41.952 --> 00:02:44.806
We're gonna be making a title function.

52
00:02:44.806 --> 00:02:49.063
We're gonna look at how to wait for it or
wait for it, figure out palindromes.

53
00:02:49.063 --> 00:02:51.620
There's a couple of other problems and

54
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:56.281
these are small that I've picked,
because they should be short to do.

55
00:02:56.281 --> 00:02:59.388
But they can have some issues
that are nice to highlight.

56
00:02:59.388 --> 00:03:04.238
And well, there's a couple other things
where we're going to hijack the Python

57
00:03:04.238 --> 00:03:07.030
system to give us some
quick iteration times.

58
00:03:07.030 --> 00:03:08.131
So I try something.

59
00:03:08.131 --> 00:03:08.810
It's broke.

60
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:10.735
It's not broke.
So being able to do that,

61
00:03:10.735 --> 00:03:15.110
that fast feedback is imperative to know,
am I on the right track?

62
00:03:15.110 --> 00:03:17.171
Or am I totally off base?

63
00:03:17.171 --> 00:03:18.600
>> Well, thank you, Justin.

64
00:03:18.600 --> 00:03:21.295
And if algorithmic problem
solving sounds like a course,

65
00:03:21.295 --> 00:03:23.391
you would be interested in and
you should be.

66
00:03:23.391 --> 00:03:27.700
Make sure to get all the episodes and
see them in our course library.

67
00:03:27.700 --> 00:03:28.689
Thanks you very much for watching.

68
00:03:28.689 --> 00:03:31.181
And remember,
a good DevPro is always learning.

69
00:03:31.181 --> 00:03:36.291
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore how to approach solving a problem algorithmically.
episodes.title: Approaching a Problem

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the problem of finding the maximum number in a list of numbers...
episodes.title: Find the Maximum: Planning

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach implement the solution to finding the maximum of a list of numbers. Justin programs while explaining the thought process behind the solution.
episodes.title: Find the Maximum: Coding

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne use the problem solving processes to explore and develop a plan to reverse a string.
episodes.title: Reversing a String: Planning

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach implement the programmatic reversing of a string. Moreover, Justin explores how to take the initial solution and changes to make to increase the readability of the source code.
episodes.title: Reversing a String: Coding

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss what a palindrome is as well as explore and develop a plan for determining if a string is a palindrome is or not.
episodes.title: Detect Palindromes: Planning

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach implement a function to determine whether a word or phrase is a palindrome. Justin demonstrates the coding process while providing reasoning about the steps that is he taking during the implementation of the function.
episodes.title: Detect Palindromes: Coding

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss the impetus for why you would create a function that would titlecase a string.
episodes.title: Creating a Title: Planning

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach create a function that provides a title case version of a supplied string. Justin further explores how to take a first pass solution and make changes to increase readability.
episodes.title: Creating a Title: Coding

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne discuss what a Caesar Cipher is as well as create a plan, after exploring the problem, necessary for implementing a caesar cipher function.
episodes.title: Caesar Cipher: Planning

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Zach implement a basic Caesar cipher function that will take a string and a number of character shifts to apply to the incoming string. Justin demonstrates how a first solution may handle all of the edge cases appropriately and how one could fix those issues.
episodes.title: Caesar Cipher: Coding
